comments.commentBody: Okay, we've seen enough of Sanchez.  Next contestant.

Whenever anything negative emerges from Idaho, the same old stereotypes of this state and tossed around by those who have never lived here or even been here. I have lived all over this country, including large eastern cities and I have never lived in a place with fewer racist remarks than Boise. You may not believe that, but you need to get out of your coccoon and realize that racists and gun-nuts live everywhere.

When northern Idaho had its problems 10 to 20 years ago with various racist groups, the community here responded with a campaign that Idaho was "too great to hate". There were virtually no Jewish people here, and yet the city erected an Anne Frank Memorial. There were almost no blacks, and a Museum of African American History was started. There's no denying the conservative and libertarian bent of the state, but the vast majority of people who live here do so for its lifestyle.

This is a story about an unfortunate man who appears to have descended into paranoid schizophrenia. It is disgraceful that he had access to a weapon and we are all fortunate that he didn't hurt anyone.

"If his name had been Mohammed and he'd been carrying a Koran you know the right wing nutters would be screaming about him being an Islamic terrorist"

That's because we know what his motivation would be. When Baruch Goldstein shot up a Mosque killing 20+ Muslims in '94 every Muslim in the world knew he was a Jewish American and the Islamic media focused on it. Yet Muslims committ similar actions against churches in Egypt, Pakistan, Nigeria and Indonisia reguarly and the Islamic media doesn't highlight the religon of the perps. Can someone explain why it's fine to emphasise hate crimes by white groups (KKK, Aryan Nation) or hate crimes against Muslims by non-Muslims, yet it is racist to make note of it the other way?
Reading the headline, my immediate thought was, "This guy has friends? What are they like?".

comments.userLocation: Park Slope NY ,and as of July 1st  Mastic Beach
comments.commentBody: Proof that country needs good and affordable health care for all.
When I hear someone use the term antiChrist is assume they are a religious fundamentalist.  Ah religion-. the bane of our existence
Our legal system does not need to pursue this ridiculous charge.  Our society doesn't need it either.

Craziness comes in all forms, folks:  I saw people in downtown San Francisco holding signs everyday for 5 years that said Bush was Hitler and the Anti-Christ.  Let's give the generalized religion bashing a rest.

Read Gail Collins' Op-Ed, published today, about the law passed by the House that would force states to permit someone to carry a concealed weapon, if the license for the weapon was issued in a state in which carrying concealed weapons was permitted.  Mentally ill people with guns - the symbol of American democracy, Republican style.
This young man is clearly mentally ill, and it is a pure misuse of power to change him with attempted assassination of the President.

My heart goes out to the Obama children who must find a way to wrap their brains around this incident. Their Dad isn't even at home right now to help with that.  What terrorism! We must find a way to fund better mental health access in this country.

Feds are "overcharging" to get the defense to plea. If they charged with lesser charges, the prosecutors would worry that he would be acquitted, get a short bid, or end up in a mental health facility. Either way, attempted assassination a ludicrous charge.

Guy won't do life, but maybe close to it.

Too bad for him. Med and a decent therapist might have prevented this.

We are always so ready to embark on a witch hunt. It's OWS, it's Christians, it's a failure of the mental health system!
This man most likely suffers from paranoid schizophrenia. While our "mental health system" has many faults, there are also laws that prevent our mental health system from prophylactically imprisoning and involuntarily medicating people with mental illness. This is the price of a free society.
I just hope that we don't sentence another severely ill person to lifelong punishment with inflated charges.
To #58 Reagan was republican

#121: "Reading what the libs have to say make me sick."

==============

*yawn* So be sick.

Meanwhile, the adults in the room salute the Secret Service for another job well done.

I agree  the world would be better off without bigotry religion.All religion Christianity, Islam,Judaism ,Hindu, Buddhism and many other sundry religion are out of date in modern era.Though I deadly against bigotry  religions I want spirituality in my life. Material world never bring peace of mind. in human life.As everyman is unique so  he can search spirituality  in different way, some may enjoy natural beauty  in nature some  may find out peace art literature there are thousand  way to find out spirituality in thousand  thing.Some may find our spirituality even in God who is without bigotry religion.

On the driver not being charged -- this is a phenomenon that I've never seen examined in the Times, even though I've written City Room to ask for it. I don't know if drivers are often charged later, pending investigation, or what. As drivers we are taught that "pedestrians always have the right of way," so hitting one must be a violation of some sort.

It's a weird contrast with the draconian NYPD that will hold people in jail for being at the wrong place at the wrong time without ID -- kind of exemplifies how they enforce according to their own lifestyle.

Well before this happened, NYPD and DAs had it already firmly established:  kill someone with a car in NYC, and as long as you stay at the scene and are sober, you will not be charged for the actual fatality.  You may face some administrative charge like driving with a suspended license, but even if you killed someone while driving with a suspension, you will not be charged for the fatality.  Bang up job, dear "authorities."

The world needs more people like her. People who stay in the neighborhoods in which they were raised and fight to make them better.

I drive and I'm a pedestrian. And even as a careful pedestrian (looking both ways, crossing in the cross walk, with the light, never assuming that a driver sees me, etc) I have come within inches of being hit more times than I can count. Several times with my children. It's frightening.

It should be noted that if you want to kill someone and get away with it, just do it with your car.  If you're charged with anything at all, it will be a small fine and a slight inconvenience. Patricia Dolan had the courage to fight the status quo of driver privilege. It's too bad we'll have to see drivers pay the real cost of driving and parking before any real change will be affected.  Drivers have no shortage of lobbyists--pedestrians just a handful.  Now we have one less.

I worked for Halliburton in the 80's and did frac jobs. We pumped as much chemicals as we could into the ground at huge flowrates and pressures. We did it because that was our paycheck. The impact on the environment was the last thing on our list. Disposal of excess chemicals was not done in an environmentally sensitive manner. And, we couldn't drink the water where we lived and taking a shower was a scary proposition. I can only hope they are more sensitive now.....but I doubt it.

The photo accompanying this article is particularly ironic and sad. The road on which Dolan was killed had no pedestrian refuge like the one she is standing on. Maybe if there had been one so she did not have to cross a road seven lanes in width, she might still be here today.

FWIW, NYC-DOT has tried to install pedestrian refuges around the city, only to be berated by car-focused politicians and media figures.

http://www.streetsblog.org/2011/06/01/kramer-and-hikind-exaggerate-victo...

Not only it seems like tragic irony that she was killed on the way to a transportation meeting, where she might have advocated for pedestrian safety, but if one looks at a picture of the intersection where this happened, it seems to be an unsafe intersection lacking in pedestrian infrastructure. No crosswalk nearby, no lights, and many lanes of traffic to cross. This is also the sort of layout that tends to encourage speeding. So perhaps the NYPD decided that she made a mistake in crossing there, but pedestrians shouldn't have to pay for mistakes with their lives!

Why in the light of the many stories like this across the industry does fracking continue without an in-depth government investigation?   Why is Cheney's law not repealed?     Why are there always Republicans at the root of these rip-offs?  Why would the PA State legislature, and the Governor preside over the pollution of the State's water supply and rivers?     Why would we all just stand by to watch a State and it's people destroyed by greed?    Why?

#22, you should move to SW Penn and put your money where your mouth is. When your nose starts to bleed and your mouth tastes like iron filings, you will probably have a better appreciation of what it means to live in a toxic waste dump. The absurd notion that we need to use every available resource whether we are injured by that use or not is only for people who don't have to pay the consequences. Get a wider view of the world.
